hint.text:
Make groups of three digits starting from the right most digit. Now, estimate the cube root using the digit in the one's place of each group
For example, consider the cube number \(3375\). Let's divide this number into groups of three starting from the right such as \('375'\) and \('3'\).

solution.text:
\(_{{54**3}}_\)
  1. Make groups of three digits starting from the right most digit of the number. In this case,
    • \(157\)
    • \(464\)
  2. The first group i.e \(464\) will give you the one's digit of the cube root.
  3. The number \(464\) ends with \(4\). We know that \(4\) comes at the unit's place of a number only when it's cube root ends in \(4\).
  4. So, we get \(4\) at the unit's place of the cube root.
  5. Now, take another group i.e. \(157\).
  6. We know that \(5^3=125\) and \(6^3=216\). Also, \(125\lt157\lt216\). Therefore, we take the smaller number among \(5\) and \(6\) as the ten's place of the required cube root.
\(\sqrt[3]{157464}=54\)

content.text: Find the cube root of \(_{{54**3}}_\) using estimation.
